articles.headline: Air Quality in California: Devastating Fires Lead to a New Danger
articles.snippet: A week after the most destructive fire in state history ripped through this small town, the flames have been replaced by a new danger: the air.
articles.abstract: A week after the most destructive fire in state history ripped through this small town, the flames have been replaced by a new danger: the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — The wildfires that have laid waste to vast parts of California are presenting residents with a new danger: air so thick with smoke it ranks among the dirtiest in the world.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Three Percent Cash Back for a Few, and Less Debt for Many
articles.snippet: Zero Financial will cut you off if your balance gets too low, like a debit card. But it gives you lots of cash back, like a credit card. Will it work?
articles.abstract: Zero Financial will cut you off if your balance gets too low, like a debit card. But it gives you lots of cash back, like a credit card. Will it work?
articles.lead_paragraph: Zero says you can have it all.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Stacey Abrams Ends Fight for Georgia Governor With Harsh Words for Her Rival
articles.snippet: Ms. Abrams acknowledged that her Republican rival Brian Kemp would become governor, saying “the law currently allows no further viable remedy” to challenge the vote.
articles.abstract: Ms. Abrams acknowledged that her Republican rival Brian Kemp would become governor, saying “the law currently allows no further viable remedy” to challenge the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Stacey Abrams ended her Democratic bid to become governor of Georgia on Friday, acknowledging that she did not have the votes to beat her Republican rival, Brian Kemp, but sounding a defiant note by declaring that an “erosion of our democracy” had kept many of her backers from the polls.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: C.I.A. Concludes That Saudi Crown Prince Ordered Khashoggi Killed
articles.snippet: Intelligence officials briefed lawmakers on Capitol Hill this week and offered the agency’s analysis of the assassination and Prince Mohammed’s culpability.
articles.abstract: Intelligence officials briefed lawmakers on Capitol Hill this week and offered the agency’s analysis of the assassination and Prince Mohammed’s culpability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, ordered the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: How the Trump Administration Stepped Up Pursuit of WikiLeaks’s Assange
articles.snippet: As American spies worked to collect intelligence on Julian Assange, Justice Department prosecutors took steps that resulted in secret charges.
articles.abstract: As American spies worked to collect intelligence on Julian Assange, Justice Department prosecutors took steps that resulted in secret charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after he took over as C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo privately told lawmakers about a new target for American spies: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Mystery of Lost Argentine Submarine Ends a Year Later, Deep at Sea
articles.snippet: The San Juan, which disappeared with 44 aboard, was found almost 2,600 feet below the ocean’s surface by a private company the government had hired.
articles.abstract: The San Juan, which disappeared with 44 aboard, was found almost 2,600 feet below the ocean’s surface by a private company the government had hired.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — In the year since 44 Argentine sailors vanished aboard a submarine, some relatives of the missing crew members had refused to speak of their loved ones in the past tense as they held out hope for a miracle — or at least clarity as to what befell them.
articles.byline: By Daniel Politi and Mihir Zaveri

articles.headline: Hazing, Humiliation, Terror: Working While Female in Federal Prison
articles.snippet: Inmates expose themselves and threaten rape. Male guards let them do it. Women who complain are ‘pretty much blackballed.’
articles.abstract: Inmates expose themselves and threaten rape. Male guards let them do it. Women who complain are ‘pretty much blackballed.’
articles.lead_paragraph: VICTORVILLE, Calif. — Makeup, earrings and perfume are off limits. So are smiles.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Alyssa Schukar

articles.headline: In California, One Community Reflects on a Fire as Others Still Burn
articles.snippet: So it is in California that as one town is only starting to comprehend its losses, another community is commemorating their last big wildfire.
articles.abstract: So it is in California that as one town is only starting to comprehend its losses, another community is commemorating their last big wildfire.
articles.lead_paragraph: OJAI, Calif. — There is the original commencement address that Aldous Huxley gave in 1951, saved from a burning boarding school in Ojai. There is a tattered and singed American flag, too. And on wall after wall of the Ojai museum are photographs of fire and destruction.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: Facebook Fallout Ruptures Democrats’ Longtime Alliance With Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Tech giants have found key allies among Democrats for years, a bond strengthened through mutual interests and campaign donations. But a year of scandals has forced a reckoning in Washington.
articles.abstract: Tech giants have found key allies among Democrats for years, a bond strengthened through mutual interests and campaign donations. But a year of scandals has forced a reckoning in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: The alliance between Democrats and Silicon Valley has buckled and bent this year amid revelations that platforms like Facebook and Twitter allowed hateful speech, Russian propaganda and conservative-leaning “fake news” to flourish.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: America’s Election Grid Remains a Patchwork of Vulnerabilities
articles.snippet: The midterms showed that there aren’t enough qualified poll workers and that accusations of political manipulation persist. Still, the situation has improved since Bush v. Gore.
articles.abstract: The midterms showed that there aren’t enough qualified poll workers and that accusations of political manipulation persist. Still, the situation has improved since Bush v. Gore.
articles.lead_paragraph: County officials in Maryland miscalculated how many ballots they would need on Election Day — and quickly ran out in more than a dozen precincts.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire, Michael Wines and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: U.S. and China Square Off on Trade, and APEC Nations Duck for Cover
articles.snippet: The clash between President Xi Jinping and Vice President Pence left the gathering of 21 nations in Papua New Guinea in disarray, and worried.
articles.abstract: The clash between President Xi Jinping and Vice President Pence left the gathering of 21 nations in Papua New Guinea in disarray, and worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The United States and China turned a Pacific Rim trade summit this weekend into a stage where the world could do little more than stand by and watch as two great powers aggravated their battle over trade.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave

articles.headline: In ‘Digital India,’ Government Hands Out Free Phones to Win Votes
articles.snippet: The leaders of one Indian state gave 2.9 million smartphones to residents, then used them to campaign for re-election. Others may copy the model.
articles.abstract: The leaders of one Indian state gave 2.9 million smartphones to residents, then used them to campaign for re-election. Others may copy the model.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAIPUR, India — Forget the old American campaign slogan of a chicken in every pot, or the Indian politician’s common pledge to put rice in every bowl.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: If Not Pelosi, Who Should Lead? The Question Hovers Over a Simmering Rebellion
articles.snippet: Among House Democrats, some strongly believe it is time for Nancy Pelosi to step aside for new leadership. But a serious challenger has yet to step forward.
articles.abstract: Among House Democrats, some strongly believe it is time for Nancy Pelosi to step aside for new leadership. But a serious challenger has yet to step forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What if House Democrats tried to stage a coup and nobody showed up?
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: The Facebook Movie Told Us What We Needed to Know About Mark Zuckerberg
articles.snippet: Rewatching “The Social Network,” eight years later: What seemed like an underdog story at the time is now more of a warning.
articles.abstract: Rewatching “The Social Network,” eight years later: What seemed like an underdog story at the time is now more of a warning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everything we needed to know about Facebook was right in front of our faces, on the big screen, in 2010.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Charges of Vote Stealing in Florida Portend More Distrust in System for 2020
articles.snippet: More than just a flashback to 2000, the Florida recount is an ominous dry run for messaging about vote-stealing that will further erode confidence in the election process.
articles.abstract: More than just a flashback to 2000, the Florida recount is an ominous dry run for messaging about vote-stealing that will further erode confidence in the election process.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The chaotic images out of Florida’s election recount last week — the brigade of Washington lawyers, the déjà vu meltdown of the tallying in Broward County, the vitriolic charges and countercharges — have prompted flashbacks among the electorate of the 2000 presidential election.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Despite Evidence on Khashoggi, Trump Sticks With the Crown Prince. Why?
articles.snippet: President Trump does not even want to listen to evidence that could shake his confidence in the Saudi royal, a decision driven by Middle East strategy and arms sales.
articles.abstract: President Trump does not even want to listen to evidence that could shake his confidence in the Saudi royal, a decision driven by Middle East strategy and arms sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As evidence piles up pointing to the Saudi crown prince’s responsibility in the brutal killing of the dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi, President Trump has only hardened his refusal to concede any possibility that the prince had a hand in the crime.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler

articles.headline: Needing Growth, Uber Returns to Germany. This Time on Best Behavior.
articles.snippet: Uber retreated from many towns in Germany in 2015 after battling regulators. Now the ride-hailing company has re-entered the city of Düsseldorf.
articles.abstract: Uber retreated from many towns in Germany in 2015 after battling regulators. Now the ride-hailing company has re-entered the city of Düsseldorf.
articles.lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Guido Goebel stopped driving for Uber three years ago when the company abandoned his hometown, the German city of Düsseldorf, after a battle with regulators.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: A $12 Billion Program to Help Farmers Stung by Trump’s Trade War Has Aided Few
articles.snippet: Only $838 million has been paid out so far, despite a promised $12 billion in subsidies to farmers whose products have been retaliated against in the trade war.
articles.abstract: Only $838 million has been paid out so far, despite a promised $12 billion in subsidies to farmers whose products have been retaliated against in the trade war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s farmers have been shut out of foreign markets, hit with retaliatory tariffs and lost lucrative contracts in the face of President Trump’s trade war. But a $12 billion bailout program Mr. Trump created to “make it up” to farmers has done little to cushion the blow, with red tape and long waiting periods resulting in few payouts so far.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, Is Arrested Over Financial Misconduct Allegations
articles.snippet: The company said Mr. Ghosn had underreported his compensation to the Japanese authorities for several years and that it was cooperating with prosecutors.
articles.abstract: The company said Mr. Ghosn had underreported his compensation to the Japanese authorities for several years and that it was cooperating with prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Carlos Ghosn, who created an alliance between Nissan and Renault that made it effectively the world’s largest carmaker, was arrested by the authorities in Japan on Monday in a remarkable tumble for one of the industry’s most powerful and admired leaders.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Founder’s Big Idea to Revive BuzzFeed’s Fortunes? A Merger With Rivals
articles.snippet: Jonah Peretti, the chief executive, says his company could eventually merge with other online publishers in order to negotiate better terms with tech platforms like Facebook.
articles.abstract: Jonah Peretti, the chief executive, says his company could eventually merge with other online publishers in order to negotiate better terms with tech platforms like Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed has long positioned itself as the future of publishing — it practices the mysterious arts of digital media better than anyone. From the beginning, its ability to know, before anyone else, what sort of content would go viral delivered it a large audience and helped the company attract half a billion dollars in venture money and a steady stream of mostly positive media attention.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee
